metadata.title: When the illiberal and the neoliberal meet around infectious diseases: an examination of the MERS response in South Korea
metadata.author: So Hyung Lim, Kristin Sziarto
affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, USA.
Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, USA.
metadata.abstract: This paper investigates infectious disease mismanagement as a way of understanding the mixture of neoliberal and illiberal governance in public health. While acknowledging the significant role of neoliberalization in public health, we call for tracing geographies of illiberalism in relation to various actors, and through various scales and processes of governance, such as private power and state absence. Through a case study of the spread of Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) throughout South Korea in 2015, this research demonstrates how neoliberal transformations in public health and illiberal practices of disease management allowed a severe outbreak of MERS, while being of benefit to a few private actors. In the MERS response, state absence via non-response such as cover-ups and censorship exacerbated state violence such as drastic quarantine and othering. Further, the South Korean government–chaebol nexus has profoundly privatized both disease management and public health, as well as intensified the responsibilization of individuals. By explaining how illiberal and neoliberal processes and particular actors came to matter in politics of infectious diseases in Korea, this paper contributes to the sociopolitical understanding of infectious diseases and public health in a mixture of authoritarianism and neoliberalism. KEYWORDS infectious diseases; illiberalism; authoritarian neoliberalism; Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS); concealment; quarantine; chaebols; Samsung

Yet, the Korean government has allowed private health insurance since 2002 (Song, 2012). 2. Chaebols are family-owned business conglomerates in South Korea. Former President and General Park Chunghee became notorious for playing a determinant role in the emergence of several chaebols and their collusion with the central governments. The chaebols have received special favours from South Korean governments, such as tax cuts and illegal mergers, in return for kickbacks and other payments; the governments have supported and invested in those big business groups in many industries, despite these corporations’ antitrust concerns, financial scandals, viral marketing and labour abuses (Kim, 2012). 3. Pressian, a Korean progressive newspaper, first exposed the existence of the outbreak and the name of the first hospital where MERS spread (Kang, 2015). On the 22nd day of the MERS outbreak, the Mayor of Seoul City, Park Wonsoon, held a press conference and revealed that the 35th index patient had contact with 1500 people in Seoul downtown within a few hours, then announced that he would take action to protect Seoul citizens’ health due to the central government’s lack of response (Korea Herald, 2015b). These events were key factors in pressuring the Korean government even to admit MERS’s existence in the country.
introduction: This paper investigates infectious disease mismanagement as a way of understanding the mixture of neoliberal and illiberal governance in public health. While acknowledging the significant role of neoliberalization in public health, we call for tracing geographies of illiberalism in relation to various actors, and through various scales and processes of governance, such as private power and state absence. Through a case study of the spread of Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) throughout South Korea in 2015, this research demonstrates how neoliberal transformations in public health and illiberal practices of disease management allowed a severe outbreak of MERS, while being of benefit to a few private actors. In the MERS response, state absence via non-response such as cover-ups and censorship exacerbated state violence such as drastic quarantine and othering. Further, the South Korean government–chaebol nexus has profoundly privatized both disease management and public health, as well as intensified the responsibilization of individuals. By explaining how illiberal and neoliberal processes and particular actors came to matter in politics of infectious diseases in Korea, this paper contributes to the sociopolitical understanding of infectious diseases and public health in a mixture of authoritarianism and neoliberalism. KEYWORDS infectious diseases; illiberalism; authoritarian neoliberalism; Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS); concealment; quarantine; chaebols; Samsung

Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), first identified in Saudi Arabia in 2012, is a recently evolved viral respiratory disease caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV) (WHO, 2015a). The virus passes via close contact and MERS has represented a relatively low risk globally, that is, less easily spread than other emerging infectious diseases (EIDs) categorized as pandemics by the World Health Organization (WHO). Yet, the MERS crisis in South Korea in 2015 deserves attention for what it shows about public health governance and the politics of infectious diseases.

CONCLUSIONS: According to Article 36(3) of the Constitution of the Republic of Korea, ‘[i]n terms of public health, all citizens are protected by the government’ (The Constitution of the Republic of Korea, 1987). Indeed, disease management has been regarded as an important role of authorities even in pre-modern times. Yet, from start to finish, and despite Korea’s democratization in the last two decades, the MERS case in Korea reveals an assemblage of neo- and ill-liberal decisions and policies. Most Korean people found little help from the state to ensure their health and lives, while a few chaebols received tremendous help to protect wealthy lives. The botched MERS response in Korea shows how the liberal, the neoliberal and the illiberal can become entangled in an EID event. In this case, with attention to the particular context of the outbreak, we see how the Korean state–chaebol nexus enabled or encouraged harm through state absence in some spaces, but once the epidemic was public, there was a clear increase in state violence. Nevertheless, this is not authoritarianism: the mayor of Seoul, and much of the media, criticized the government and demanded other kinds of policies.

In closing, we find two avenues where we can make further contributions. First, disease mismanagement and public health crises continue to be important phenomena from which we can learn about illiberal governance, processes and practices. During the past 35 years, nearly onethird of the world’s deaths were caused by EIDs, and mortality and morbidity related to infectious diseases worldwide are increasing (Global Burden of Disease 2016; Causes of Death Collaborators, 2017) – we are witnessing ‘an epidemic of epidemics’ (Elbe, 2018, p. 1). Illiberal practices operate in an overall hegemonic international system, and South Korea is not the only illiberal/ neoliberal venue that turns to austerity and coercion in the face of infectious diseases. We need still more research on disease response and public health attending to the actually existing illiberal and neoliberal processes in disease responses in various contexts. Examining such processes will continue to reveal the importance of shifting relations among variously scaled agencies and bodies, of careful conceptualization of practices and the state, and of mutually constitutive spatialities amid the growing scholarly research on global public health. We still need greater attention to the roles of private or commercial interests in urban, national and global health governance.

Second, the South Korean case exemplifies phenomena that cannot be explained solely by neoliberalism nor illiberalism. To pursue these inquiries further, we need more interdisciplinary conversations. The literature on illiberalism first developed by social scientists and anthropologists recognizes ill- and neo-liberal practices in supposedly liberal states. Geographical perspectives can broaden the illiberalism scholarship with a critique of the unitary state and of state-centrism, as well as by problematizing the dichotomies of liberal/illiberal and the imaginative geographies deploying that dichotomy. This paper also complements the argument regarding variegated neoliberalism (Brenner, Peck, & Theodore, 2010; Peck, 2013), and highlights the need for scrutinizing more pluralist usages of politics and governance (Agnew, 2013) regarding public health.

participants.context: Several years before the MERS crisis, South Korea had been regarded as one of the states most capable of containing infectious viruses. <mark class="stats">When Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) emerged in China in 2002 to cause around 800 deaths and 8100 cases in 37 countries, the WHO praised the South Korean government as having ‘exemplary’ health authorities with effective disease prevention, given that there were no deaths from SARS in Korea despite the geographical proximity between China and Korea (WHO, 2004)</mark>. It is remarkable that 12 years later, in 2015, South Korea’s reputation was sullied owing to the central government’s ‘inability’ to control the spread of MERS (WHO, 2015a), which is a quite similar respiratory disease to SARS (Hui, Perlman, & Zumla, 2015)

On the other hand, by the time of the 18th case of the MERS virus in Korea, no beds in public hospitals were available, nor were there single rooms with negative-pressure isolation (Woo et al, 2017). Ironically, at the time of the MERS outbreak, South Korea had the second largest number of hospital beds – 10 beds to spare for 1000 people – among the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) states. However, approximately 88% of them were run by private hospitals and clinics (Woo et al, 2017), as well as 30 tertiary hospitals among which 43 in total were privately owned (Britnell, 2015)

Compared with the N1H1 flu in 2009, the number of quarantines during the MERS outbreak was far greater, and the degree of isolation more intense, despite the fact the 2009 flu is regarded as a much deadlier disease.5. During the H1N1 pandemic, approximately 400 individuals were quarantined either in their households or assigned sites during the first three months, when the number of confirmed patients was 1300. In the MERS epidemic, approximately 16,000 individuals were quarantined in the first month when there were only 150 confirmed cases (Lee, 2015)

During the H1N1 pandemic, approximately 400 individuals were quarantined either in their households or assigned sites during the first three months, when the number of confirmed patients was 1300. In the MERS epidemic, approximately 16,000 individuals were quarantined in the first month when there were only 150 confirmed cases (Lee, 2015). In total, throughout the MERS response, about 16,800 people were quarantined or under observation, about 30 hospitals were shut down and over 1100 schools had to close their doors for a few weeks or up to a month (Healthcare and Society Forum, 2015)

In the MERS epidemic, approximately 16,000 individuals were quarantined in the first month when there were only 150 confirmed cases (Lee, 2015). In total, throughout the MERS response, about 16,800 people were quarantined or under observation, about 30 hospitals were shut down and over 1100 schools had to close their doors for a few weeks or up to a month (Healthcare and Society Forum, 2015). The greater use of quarantine, however, was not an effective strategy to respond to the MERS epidemic

Koreans originally created the new online community because they wanted to protect themselves from the disease by exchanging useful information, amid the lack of government announcements or safety regulations. However, once a rumour in the forum spread that two infected women refused to be quarantined and went on a shopping trip, a misogynistic atmosphere surged in this online forum and elsewhere, inciting hate crimes, despite counter-measures by a few feminist advocacy groups (Jang, 2016; Jang & Ryu, 2017). Although such activities intensified gendered conflicts, and this intensification has persisted into the present, the Korean government has not addressed any of these aftermaths of the MERS outbreak

Mega-hospitals South Korea currently has more than 10 mega-hospitals usually run by chaebols and located in Seoul. By mega-hospital, we mean a Korean tertiary hospital with at least 2000 beds, 8000 medical staff and 600,000 inpatients per year, as well as its own medical research institutions. A tertiary hospital is a facility that offers tertiary healthcare and requires a referral from primary or secondary care (Oh & Kim, 2009)

participants.context: When the government announced the closure of several tertiary hospitals as well as a thorough investigation, SMC was the only one found not to conform to the emergency regulations (Korea Herald, 2015b). SMC managed MERS by itself without following the government’s directions, and its lax regulations led to 92 patients with MERS and 9793 persons exposed (Park et al, 2016), accounting for nearly half of the total cases in South Korea. Many infections occurred because a doctor at SMC, by participating in outdoor activities, exposed 1565 people in one day

SMC managed MERS by itself without following the government’s directions, and its lax regulations led to 92 patients with MERS and 9793 persons exposed (Park et al, 2016), accounting for nearly half of the total cases in South Korea. Many infections occurred because a doctor at SMC, by participating in outdoor activities, exposed 1565 people in one day. Additional internal infections occurred via the hospital’s transport, cleaning and sanitary workers

Given that there was no government investigation or regulation of SMC when it was spreading MERS, it seems the government–Samsung bond, Samsung’s epidemic mismanagement and precarious labour conditions were as pernicious as the virus itself. <mark class="stats">SMC’s responsibility was officially expunged, since two leaders of Samsung offered public apologies (Korea Herald, 2015b)</mark>. Nevertheless, an exceptional advantage for Samsung remained during and after the outbreak, while the rest of the country suffered from illiberal health governance

Pressian, a Korean progressive newspaper, first exposed the existence of the outbreak and the name of the first hospital where MERS spread (Kang, 2015). <mark class="stats">On the 22nd day of the MERS outbreak, the Mayor of Seoul City, Park Wonsoon, held a press conference and revealed that the 35th index patient had contact with 1500 people in Seoul downtown within a few hours, then announced that he would take action to protect Seoul citizens’ health due to the central government’s lack of response (Korea Herald, 2015b)</mark>. These events were key factors in pressuring the Korean government even to admit MERS’s existence in the country
5. The H1N1 flu killed around 203,000 and infected over 20 million people in more than 214 countries. The WHO labelled it as a pandemic (Kim, 2016b), whereas MERS is still categorized as an epidemic

summary:
Introduction:

This paper investigates infectious disease mismanagement as a way of understanding the mixture of neoliberal and illiberal governance in public health.

Through a case study of the spread of Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) throughout South Korea in 2015, this research demonstrates how neoliberal transformations in public health and illiberal practices of disease management allowed a severe outbreak of MERS, while being of benefit to a few private actors.
The MERS crisis in South Korea in 2015 deserves attention for what it shows about public health governance and the politics of infectious diseases

Conclusion:

According to Article 36(3) of the Constitution of the Republic of Korea, ‘[i]n terms of public health, all citizens are protected by the government’ (The Constitution of the Republic of Korea, 1987).
The botched MERS response in Korea shows how the liberal, the neoliberal and the illiberal can become entangled in an EID event

In this case, with attention to the particular context of the outbreak, the authors see how the Korean state–chaebol nexus enabled or encouraged harm through state absence in some spaces, but once the epidemic was public, there was a clear increase in state violence.
This is not authoritarianism: the mayor of Seoul, and much of the media, criticized the government and demanded other kinds of policies

claims: This paper investigates infectious disease mismanagement as a way of understanding the mixture of neoliberal and illiberal governance in public health
ABSTRACT This paper investigates infectious disease mismanagement as a way of understanding the mixture of neoliberal and illiberal governance in public health

We argue that there were at least three critical areas of consideration that influenced the rapid spread of the MERS virus, none of which was named by the WHO: (1) neoliberalization of the Korean public health system over the previous two decades, which meant deterioration of the national health infrastructure; (2) the Korean government’s concealing information from the public regarding the spread of the disease; and (3) multiple actors, including international health agencies, local governments and private healthcare providers, that failed to coordinate reactions to the epidemic crises

Agreeing that liberalism has more often than not involved non-democratic, unequal and abusive manifestations, we argue that liberalism’s ill-liberal impulses in EID management – or in public health in a broader sense – need to be thoroughly scrutinized, regardless of the label we apply to the country wherein an EID outbreak occurs

In the case of the MERS epidemic in South Korea, we aim to show how socially and politically constructed pathways of ill-liberal management of EIDs led not only to a severe outbreak but also to other harmful outcomes for many people, and benefits for a select few

We argue that we should regard these spaces as sites of calculated state absence, not necessarily as part of a sequential roll-back then roll-out process, because there may be many policies already in place when neoliberalization is implemented

While we have focused on quarantine policies and othering in this subsection, it should be noted that other forms of state violence such as the media blackout, censorship and propaganda continued during this later stage
In closing, we find two avenues where we can make further contributions
key_statements: Through a case study of the spread of Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) throughout South Korea in 2015, this research demonstrates how neoliberal transformations in public health and illiberal practices of disease management allowed a severe outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome, while being of benefit to a few private actors

By explaining how illiberal and neoliberal processes and particular actors came to matter in politics of infectious diseases in Korea, this paper contributes to the sociopolitical understanding of infectious diseases and public health in a mixture of authoritarianism and neoliberalism

The virus passes via close contact and Middle East respiratory syndrome has represented a relatively low risk globally, that is, less spread than other emerging infectious diseases (EIDs) categorized as pandemics by the World Health Organization (WHO)

We argue that there were at least three critical areas of consideration that influenced the rapid spread of the Middle East respiratory syndrome virus, none of which was named by the World Health Organization: (1) neoliberalization of the Korean public health system over the previous two decades, which meant deterioration of the national health infrastructure; (2) the Korean government’s concealing information from the public regarding the spread of the disease; and (3) multiple actors, including international health agencies, local governments and private healthcare providers, that failed to coordinate reactions to the epidemic crises

While we have focused on quarantine policies and othering in this subsection, it should be noted that other forms of state violence such as the media blackout, censorship and propaganda continued during this later stage
According to Article 36(3) of the Constitution of the Republic of Korea, ‘[i]n terms of public health, all citizens are protected by the government’ (The Constitution of the Republic of Korea, 1987)
Disease management has been regarded as an important role of authorities even in pre-modern times

From start to finish, and despite Korea’s democratization in the last two decades, the Middle East respiratory syndrome case in Korea reveals an assemblage of neo- and ill-liberal decisions and policies
The botched Middle East respiratory syndrome response in Korea shows how the liberal, the neoliberal and the illiberal can become entangled in an emerging infectious diseases event
